author: SwarfegaGit
body:
I am using two Raspberry Pi's and connecting to them via a Windows 10 (Windows Feature SSH Client (Beta) installed).  Both are working fine if I do a New-PSSession to either of them individually using password authentication.  According to the help the HostName parameter supports multiple inputs (New-PSSession [-HostName] <string[]>) however it doesn't work for me.  When asked for a password it's asking for the password for both hosts at the same time.  If I enter the correct password (both use the same user/password) it errors with an access denied for the first host and then freezes.  I can't even cancel the operation (Ctrl + C) so have to close the pwsh console down.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
$PSSession = New-PSSession -HostName '192.168.0.1','192.168.0.2' -UserName pi
pi@192.168.0.1's password: pi@192.168.0.2's password:
pi@192.168.0.1's password: New-PSSession : [192.168.0.1] The background process reported an error with the following message: The SSH client session has ended with error message: Permission denied, please try again..
At line:1 char:14
+ ... PSSession = New-PSSession -HostName '192.168.0.1','192.168.0.2' -U ...
+                 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
+ CategoryInfo          : OpenError: (System.Manageme....RemoteRunspace:RemoteRunspace) [New-PSSession], PSRemotingTransportException
+ FullyQualifiedErrorId : 2100,PSSessionOpenFailed
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

```none
For a session to be established
```

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
Error is produced as above and never returns to a command prompt.
```

comments.author: PaulHigin
comments.body:
Sorry for the delayed response.  This is a bug in PowerShell, and I don't immediately see a good fix.  The problem is that PowerShell is trying to create two SSH sessions at the same time.  But PowerShell doesn't handle passwords and SSH writes directly to the terminal to prompt for the password.  But having two sessions prompting for a password at the same time causes this confusion.

One workaround is to use key based user identification rather than password based.

Another is to create the sessions separately:
```powershell
$sessions = @()
$sessions += New-PSSession -HostName 'host1' -UserName 'User'
$sessions += New-PSSession -HostName 'host2' -UserName 'User'
$results = Invoke-Command -FilePath c:\ScriptToRun.ps1 -Session $sessions
```

title: New-PSSession to Linux with more than one hostname
